LiveView

PhilJS LiveView enables real-time, server-rendered UI updates over WebSockets, providing rich interactivity without complex client-side state management.

Introduction

LiveView keeps your application logic on the server while providing a reactive, real-time user experience. The server maintains the state, handles events, and sends optimized DOM patches to the client over WebSockets.

i

Inspiration

PhilJS LiveView is inspired by Phoenix LiveView and brings similar patterns to the TypeScript/Rust ecosystem with seamless integration into the PhilJS framework.

Setup

Terminal
$pnpm add philjs-liveview
$# For Rust projects:
$cargo add philjs-liveview
server.tstypescript
1// server.ts
2import { createServer } from 'philjs-liveview/server';
3import { App } from './App';
4 
5const server = createServer({
6  component: App,
7  port: 3000,
8  // WebSocket configuration
9  ws: {
10    path: '/live',
11    heartbeat: 30000,
12  },
13});
14 
15server.listen();

Basic Example

TypeScript

Counter.tsxtypescript
1import { createLiveView, useLiveState } from 'philjs-liveview';
2 
3export const Counter = createLiveView({
4  // Initial state (runs on server)
5  mount: () => ({
6    count: 0,
7  }),
8 
9  // Event handlers (run on server)
10  handleEvent: {
11    increment: (state) => ({
12      ...state,
13      count: state.count + 1,
14    }),
15    decrement: (state) => ({
16      ...state,
17      count: state.count - 1,
18    }),
19  },
20 
21  // Render (runs on server, sends DOM patches)
22  render: (state, { pushEvent }) => (
23    <div className="counter">
24      <h1>Count: {state.count}</h1>
25      <button onClick={() => pushEvent('decrement')}>-</button>
26      <button onClick={() => pushEvent('increment')}>+</button>
27    </div>
28  ),
29});

Rust

counter.rsrust
1use philjs_liveview::prelude::*;
2 
3#[derive(Default, Clone)]
4struct CounterState {
5    count: i32,
6}
7 
8#[live_view]
9fn Counter() -> impl LiveView {
10    LiveViewBuilder::new()
11        .mount(|| CounterState::default())
12        .handle_event("increment", |state: &mut CounterState| {
13            state.count += 1;
14        })
15        .handle_event("decrement", |state: &mut CounterState| {
16            state.count -= 1;
17        })
18        .render(|state, cx| {
19            view! {
20                <div class="counter">
21                    <h1>"Count: " {state.count}</h1>
22                    <button on:click=cx.push_event("decrement")>"-"</button>
23                    <button on:click=cx.push_event("increment")">"+"</button>
24                </div>
25            }
26        })
27}

Form Handling

LiveView provides seamless form handling with real-time validation:

1import { createLiveView } from 'philjs-liveview';
2 
3export const ContactForm = createLiveView({
4  mount: () => ({
5    form: { name: '', email: '', message: '' },
6    errors: {},
7    submitted: false,
8  }),
9 
10  handleEvent: {
11    validate: (state, { field, value }) => {
12      const errors = { ...state.errors };
13 
14      if (field === 'email' && !value.includes('@')) {
15        errors.email = 'Invalid email address';
16      } else {
17        delete errors[field];
18      }
19 
20      return {
21        ...state,
22        form: { ...state.form, [field]: value },
23        errors,
24      };
25    },
26 
27    submit: async (state) => {
28      // Server-side form processing
29      await sendEmail(state.form);
30      return { ...state, submitted: true };
31    },
32  },
33 
34  render: (state, { pushEvent }) => (
35    <form onSubmit={(e) => { e.preventDefault(); pushEvent('submit'); }}>
36      <input
37        value={state.form.name}
38        onInput={(e) => pushEvent('validate', {
39          field: 'name',
40          value: e.target.value,
41        })}
42      />
43 
44      <input
45        type="email"
46        value={state.form.email}
47        onInput={(e) => pushEvent('validate', {
48          field: 'email',
49          value: e.target.value,
50        })}
51      />
52      {state.errors.email && <span>{state.errors.email}</span>}
53 
54      <textarea
55        value={state.form.message}
56        onInput={(e) => pushEvent('validate', {
57          field: 'message',
58          value: e.target.value,
59        })}
60      />
61 
62      <button type="submit">Send</button>
63    </form>
64  ),
65});

Real-Time Updates

LiveView can push updates to clients from server-side events:

1import { createLiveView } from 'philjs-liveview';
2 
3export const Dashboard = createLiveView({
4  mount: async () => ({
5    metrics: await fetchMetrics(),
6    lastUpdated: new Date(),
7  }),
8 
9  // Subscribe to server-side events
10  subscriptions: ['metrics:updated'],
11 
12  // Handle broadcast messages
13  handleInfo: {
14    'metrics:updated': async (state, payload) => ({
15      ...state,
16      metrics: payload.metrics,
17      lastUpdated: new Date(),
18    }),
19  },
20 
21  render: (state) => (
22    <div className="dashboard">
23      <h1>Live Metrics</h1>
24      <p>Last updated: {state.lastUpdated.toLocaleString()}</p>
25      <MetricsGrid metrics={state.metrics} />
26    </div>
27  ),
28});
29 
30// Broadcast updates from anywhere on the server
31import { broadcast } from 'philjs-liveview';
32 
33setInterval(async () => {
34  const metrics = await fetchMetrics();
35  broadcast('metrics:updated', { metrics });
36}, 5000);

Navigation

LiveView supports client-side navigation while maintaining WebSocket connection:

1import { createLiveView, navigate, Link } from 'philjs-liveview';
2 
3export const ProductList = createLiveView({
4  mount: async ({ params }) => ({
5    products: await fetchProducts(params.category),
6    category: params.category,
7  }),
8 
9  render: (state) => (
10    <div>
11      <nav>
12        <Link to="/products/electronics">Electronics</Link>
13        <Link to="/products/clothing">Clothing</Link>
14      </nav>
15 
16      <ul>
17        {state.products.map(product => (
18          <li key={product.id}>
19            <Link to={`/products/${product.id}`}>
20              {product.name}
21            </Link>
22          </li>
23        ))}
24      </ul>
25    </div>
26  ),
27});

File Uploads

1import { createLiveView } from 'philjs-liveview';
2 
3export const ImageUpload = createLiveView({
4  mount: () => ({
5    uploads: [],
6    progress: {},
7  }),
8 
9  // Configure uploads
10  uploads: {
11    images: {
12      accept: ['image/*'],
13      maxSize: 5 * 1024 * 1024, // 5MB
14      maxEntries: 5,
15    },
16  },
17 
18  handleEvent: {
19    upload: async (state, { uploads }, { consumeUpload }) => {
20      const uploaded = [];
21      for (const upload of uploads.images) {
22        const url = await consumeUpload(upload, saveToStorage);
23        uploaded.push({ name: upload.name, url });
24      }
25      return { ...state, uploads: [...state.uploads, ...uploaded] };
26    },
27  },
28 
29  render: (state, { uploads, pushEvent }) => (
30    <div>
31      <input
32        type="file"
33        multiple
34        accept="image/*"
35        onChange={(e) => uploads.images.addFiles(e.target.files)}
36      />
37 
38      {uploads.images.entries.map(entry => (
39        <div key={entry.ref}>
40          {entry.name} - {entry.progress}%
41        </div>
42      ))}
43 
44      <button onClick={() => pushEvent('upload')}>
45        Upload
46      </button>
47    </div>
48  ),
49});

JavaScript Hooks

For complex client-side behavior, use JavaScript hooks:

1// hooks.ts
2export const Hooks = {
3  Chart: {
4    mounted() {
5      this.chart = new Chart(this.el, {
6        data: JSON.parse(this.el.dataset.points),
7      });
8    },
9    updated() {
10      this.chart.update(JSON.parse(this.el.dataset.points));
11    },
12    destroyed() {
13      this.chart.destroy();
14    },
15  },
16};
17 
18// In your LiveView
19render: (state) => (
20  <canvas
21    phx-hook="Chart"
22    data-points={JSON.stringify(state.chartData)}
23  />
24)

Axum Integration (Rust)

main.rsrust
1use axum::{routing::get, Router};
2use philjs_liveview::{LiveViewLayer, live};
3 
4#[tokio::main]
5async fn main() {
6    let app = Router::new()
7        .route("/", get(home))
8        .route("/counter", live(Counter))
9        .route("/dashboard", live(Dashboard))
10        .layer(LiveViewLayer::new());
11 
12    axum::Server::bind(&"0.0.0.0:3000".parse().unwrap())
13        .serve(app.into_make_service())
14        .await
15        .unwrap();
16}

Best Practices

  • Keep state minimal: Only store what's needed for rendering
  • Debounce frequent events: Use built-in debouncing for inputs
  • Handle disconnections: Implement reconnection logic for robustness
  • Use hooks sparingly: Prefer server-side logic when possible
  • Optimize subscriptions: Unsubscribe from topics when not needed
